body:
thanks Dave, 
Hi, Hans, I have changed the checking logic to make more restriction:

  if (newGivenType->getTypeQualifier() == NA_CHARACTER_TYPE &&
-      (CmpCommon::getDefaultString(HIVE_FILE_CHARSET) == "GBK" || CmpCommon::getDefaultString(HIVE_FILE_CHARSET) == "gbk") && CmpCommon::getDefaultString(HIVE_DEFAULT_CHARSET) == "UTF8" )
-        needTranslate = TRUE;

So it will only do a translate when the HIVE_FILE_CHARSET is set to 'GBK'/'gbk' and HIVE_DEFAULT_CHARSET is 'UTF8'. 

thanks,
Ming
Looks good to me. Thanks for fixing all those typos.
Just wanted to check: Is this ready for commit?

I'm not exactly sure Dave, but there were conflicts needing resolution when I did the merge.  This is in the generated code area, so I probably shouldn't try to manually resolve conflicts there.  I should instead resolve the conflicts in the source files and rebuild the generated code.  Let me see if I can do that and recreate the pull request.

I just rebuilt the generated/TrxRegionProtos.java file and after reionserting the copyright block at the head of the file it is exactly the same, so I believe it is correct.  There are various auto generated methos got building the protobufs for the requests and replies and these all have the required 5th parameter which is set in the TrxRegion.proto file.  I think this is normal.

Thanks for raising this Dave.  It's always good to verify.

Sean
Ok with me, too. Now that we use only non-ephemeral port ranges, do we really need this?

Yes.  I was not able to install Trafodion successfully without going
through non-ephemeral ports that are currently occupied (as revealed by
sudo lsof).

This automates the process.

Thanks

Looks great.

Does the build instructions on the web page need to change to install apr and apr-utils? 

Also, as part of testing release 1.3.0, I tested the build by not using the TOOLSDIR but setting up each tool location as a separate environment variable export. So I created a set of exports for LLVM, ICU, MAVEN, etc.  Should we make sure this works with adding CXX to the picture.
Yes, I think it is and I'll commit it shortly.

Yes, I will update the wiki page on setting up the build environment, once this change is in. 

Yes, you could definitely have the LOG4CXX location be somewhere other than TOOLSDIR. Did you want me to add the variables to core/sqf/LocalSettingsTemplate.sh to highlight that?

Changing LocalSettingsTemplate.sh would be good.

```
Roberta
```

Yes, I think I've addressed Roberta's suggestion. Should be good to go.

I'm missing something. In optimizer/ItemExpr.cpp, I see that a variable was renamed. And in optimizer/NormRelExpr.cpp, I see that some code was re-indented. And I see changes to regression tests. But that's it. What code change fixed the bug? What did I miss?
Never mind. I see it in the ItemExpr.cpp code. I missed the added 'if'. Code change looks good to me.
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/405/
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Looks good to me. Thanks for doing this, Ming.

Great question.  Let me explain what we currently see, and why the proposed change as part of my explanation.

The server hands out 64 bit IDs based on an AtomicLong it stores internally.  This value is initialized at startup to the current system time and is monotonically increased with each request.  What we see today is that the ID is very strongly correlated to system time at startup, but over time the ID values begin to trail very substantially from the system clock.  This is because the requests don't come in with the frequency of time clicks.

The proposed change is to try to periodically refresh the internal ID based on the current system time so that it stays closer to the system time.  This would have the observable effect of the returned IDs making periodic leaps FORWARD, not backward.

The same would be true of IDs following a system shutdown.  The new system time is ahead of the previous system time or ID and could never go backwards... unless...

Unless the system clocks are reset.  If the system clocks are reset, then yes the IDs could go backwards and this would have the same effect as setting the clocks backwards today.  It would depend on many variables - how far back did the time get set, what was the latest time used in the database, etc.  In practice I don't think this is very likely to affect anyone.
Code changes look good to me. Thanks for the explanation.
Looks good! Thanks for making this faster.
Looks good Venkat. Merging in now.

This is strange, I made a brand new building machine , install a CentOS6.5, Then follow the build instruction and it failed at DCS build. I made this change and it can build. But without this change, DCS can be built before, so I am not sure if this is required, just send it out for expert to review.
At least it is good thing to add dependency in the pom.xml.
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?

llvm, bison is also avialble via yum installation. But it will install them into 'system default' folder, like /usr/lib and /usr/include, so the Makefile need change as well. But if that is doable, I think it will further greatly improve the speed.
It needs some non-trivial effort, so just my 2 cents.
Looks good to me. To be clear, this change enables DDL transactions but doesn't turn them on by default, correct? (For the latter, we'd need to change the default for CQD DDL_TRANSACTIONS to 'ON'?)

That is correct. 
The thought is for this code to be exercised in daily build and regression tests. 

Parser flag and cqd need to be set to use this feature in a controlled environment. ( see regression test for the parser flag and cqd setting )

Regards,
Prashanth
